content: The Act may be known as the "National Firearms Exchange Act." It includes findings and purpose statements. The National Firearms Exchange Act aims to address the issue of violence related to firearms by authorizing programs that exchange merchandise vouchers for firearms, providing grants for these programs, and offering amnesty for individuals surrendering firearms under the programs. The National Firearms Exchange Act authorizes programs exchanging merchandise vouchers for firearms, providing grants, and offering amnesty for surrendering firearms. Additionally, taxpayers can receive a tax deduction for donating merchandise vouchers for the programs. Title I of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include programs exchanging merchandise vouchers for firearms. The Director of the Bureau of Justice Assistance will establish procedures for local governments to apply for approval of programs exchanging merchandise vouchers for firearms. Factors considered include the characteristics of the local government, types of firearms involved, disposal methods for surrendered firearms, and acceptance of firearms from residents of other states. The program exchanging merchandise vouchers for firearms will consider factors such as protecting anonymity, immunity from prosecution for surrendering firearms, and surrendering firearms in exchange for a voucher. The Director must approve firearm surrender programs that ensure all surrendered firearms will be destroyed, except those needed for investigatory or evidentiary purposes. Approved programs are valid for a 2-year period and can reapply for subsequent periods. Efforts will be made to secure State amnesty for individuals surrendering firearms to approved programs.
